A **water elemental**, E, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is an [amphibious](/wiki/Amphibious "Amphibious"), [unsolid](/wiki/Unsolid "Unsolid") [elemental](/wiki/Elemental "Elemental") that is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") and capable of [swimming](/wiki/Swimming "Swimming").

A water elemental has a single strong claw attack, and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and [stoning resistance](/wiki/Stoning_resistance "Stoning resistance").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 NetHack brass](#NetHack_brass)
  - [4.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.4 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [4.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [4.6 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [5 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated water elementals may be [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") towards [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") characters. Water elementals generated on the [Plane of Water](/wiki/Plane_of_Water "Plane of Water") will have three times as many hit points.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

In addition to random generation, a water elemental may be generated as a [minion](/wiki/Minion "Minion") of a neutral [god](/wiki/God "God"). [Quaffing](/wiki/Quaff "Quaff") from a [sink](/wiki/Sink "Sink") has a 1⁄20 chance of generating a water elemental if they are not [extinct](/wiki/Extinct "Extinct").

Water elementals appear among the random E that are part of the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for [Monks](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Monk quest](/wiki/Monk_quest "Monk quest"). They also appear among the the random E that are part of the second quest class for [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai"), and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Samurai quest](/wiki/Samurai_quest "Samurai quest").

Nineteen hostile water elementals are generated across the Plane of Water at level creation.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

Water elementals are not a valid target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"). A water elemental [does not leave a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless") upon death.

## Strategy

Water elementals have the strongest single attack among elementals, but are incredibly slow at 6 base [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") and lack any of the abilities that some other elementals possess, meaning they can easily be outrun and kited.

On the Plane of Water, the water elementals are usually the least threatening monsters present: most of the level is populated with [sea monsters](/wiki/Sea_monster "Sea monster") that can instantly kill a character via [drowning](/wiki/Drowning "Drowning"), making it common to read a blessed [scroll of genocide](/wiki/Scroll_of_genocide "Scroll of genocide") immediately after entering the Plane. Once the Plane's drowning threats are dealt with, water elementals are considered an annoyance at worst, as most characters will be more than able to handle their melee attacks.

## History

The water elemental first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), at least one water elemental is generated within the Cloud Bank of the [Lawful Quest](/wiki/Lawful_Quest "Lawful Quest") at level creation, with a 3⁄5 chance of a second one being placed nearby.

Water elementals feature prominently in the [Flame Mage quest](/wiki/Flame_Mage_quest "Flame Mage quest"): They are the first quest monster class for [Flame Mages](/wiki/Flame_Mage "Flame Mage"), and make up 96⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on their quest. Several water elementals are also generated on each floor of the quest branch at level creation: six are generated on the home level, seven are generated on the filler levels, nine are generated on the locate level, and twelve are generated on the goal level.

The Ice Mage [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"), [The Storm Whistle](/wiki/The_Storm_Whistle "The Storm Whistle"), can be [invoked](/wiki/Invoked "Invoked") to summon tame water elementals.

### NetHack brass

In [NetHack brass](/wiki/NetHack_brass "NetHack brass"), water elementals are given an additional engulfing attack that can cause a [delayed instadeath](/wiki/Delayed_instadeath "Delayed instadeath") by [strangulation](/wiki/Strangulation "Strangulation") (which is flavored as "drowning" while being distinct from [drowning attacks](/wiki/Drowning_attack "Drowning attack")) and a rust-inducing passive. This makes them among the more dangerous elementals to encounter, as their engulfing can suffocate you if you do not break out in time, and will often cause significant water damage to your even if you survive.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), 1⁄10 of the monsters randomly generated on the Water Temple level of the [Chaos Temple Quest](/wiki/Chaos_Temple_Quest "Chaos Temple Quest") will be water elementals.

Water elementals take double damage from the Horrid Wilting active power of [Iris, Friend from Afar](/wiki/Spirits_\(dNetHack\)#Iris.2C_Friend_from_Afar "Spirits (dNetHack)").

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), a hostile water elemental is generated on the [Plane of Ice](/wiki/Plane_of_Ice "Plane of Ice") at level creation.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), water elementals are given a rust-inducing passive and an additional engulfing attack that causes delayed instadeath by suffocation, similar to NetHack brass.

### SlashTHEM

[SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") adds the [greater water elemental](/index.php?title=Greater_water_elemental\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Greater water elemental (page does not exist)"), though water elementals cannot grow up into them. Water elementals leave behind [shallow water](/wiki/Shallow_water "Shallow water") upon death, and are generated in the same levels as in SLASH'EM.

The [Firefighter](/wiki/Firefighter "Firefighter") quest artifact, the [Fire Chief Helmet](/wiki/Fire_Chief_Helmet "Fire Chief Helmet"), can be invoked to summon tame water elementals, with a 3⁄4 chance of generating a standard water elemental and a 1⁄4 chance of generating a greater one. The Storm Whistle is changed to instead summon tame [ice elementals](/wiki/Ice_elemental "Ice elemental") and [ice vortices](/wiki/Ice_vortices "Ice vortices").

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 45](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L45): *elementals and home planes*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1012](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L1012): *max HP for elementals on home planes*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1825](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L1825): *max HP gain for elementals on home planes*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [dat/endgame.des in NetHack 3.6.7, line 457](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/dat/endgame.des#L457)

E water elemental
Difficulty 10
Attacks

Claw 5d6

Base level 8
Base experience 126
Speed 6
Base AC 2
Base MR 30
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable No
Weight 2500
Nutritional value 0
Size huge
Resistances poison, petrification
Resistances conveyed None

A water elemental:

  • can swim.
  • can survive underwater.
  • has no eyes.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is strong.
  • never leaves a corpse.
Reference monst.c#line1387

A water elemental, E, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is an amphibious, unsolid elemental that is strong and capable of swimming.

A water elemental has a single strong claw attack, and possesses poison resistance and stoning resistance.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 NetHack brass
    • 4.3 dNetHack
    • 4.4 SpliceHack
    • 4.5 EvilHack
    • 4.6 SlashTHEM
  • 5 References

Generation

Randomly generated water elementals may be peaceful towards neutral characters. Water elementals generated on the Plane of Water will have three times as many hit points.[1][2][3]

In addition to random generation, a water elemental may be generated as a minion of a neutral god. Quaffing from a sink has a 1⁄20 chance of generating a water elemental if they are not extinct.

Water elementals appear among the random E that are part of the first quest monster class for Monks, and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Monk quest. They also appear among the the random E that are part of the second quest class for Samurai, and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Samurai quest.

Nineteen hostile water elementals are generated across the Plane of Water at level creation.[4]

Water elementals are not a valid target for genocide. A water elemental does not leave a corpse upon death.

Strategy

Water elementals have the strongest single attack among elementals, but are incredibly slow at 6 base speed and lack any of the abilities that some other elementals possess, meaning they can easily be outrun and kited.

On the Plane of Water, the water elementals are usually the least threatening monsters present: most of the level is populated with sea monsters that can instantly kill a character via drowning, making it common to read a blessed scroll of genocide immediately after entering the Plane. Once the Plane's drowning threats are dealt with, water elementals are considered an annoyance at worst, as most characters will be more than able to handle their melee attacks.

History

The water elemental first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, at least one water elemental is generated within the Cloud Bank of the Lawful Quest at level creation, with a 3⁄5 chance of a second one being placed nearby.

Water elementals feature prominently in the Flame Mage quest: They are the first quest monster class for Flame Mages, and make up 96⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on their quest. Several water elementals are also generated on each floor of the quest branch at level creation: six are generated on the home level, seven are generated on the filler levels, nine are generated on the locate level, and twelve are generated on the goal level.

The Ice Mage quest artifact, The Storm Whistle, can be invoked to summon tame water elementals.

NetHack brass

In NetHack brass, water elementals are given an additional engulfing attack that can cause a delayed instadeath by strangulation (which is flavored as "drowning" while being distinct from drowning attacks) and a rust-inducing passive. This makes them among the more dangerous elementals to encounter, as their engulfing can suffocate you if you do not break out in time, and will often cause significant water damage to your even if you survive.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, 1⁄10 of the monsters randomly generated on the Water Temple level of the Chaos Temple Quest will be water elementals.

Water elementals take double damage from the Horrid Wilting active power of Iris, Friend from Afar.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack, a hostile water elemental is generated on the Plane of Ice at level creation.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, water elementals are given a rust-inducing passive and an additional engulfing attack that causes delayed instadeath by suffocation, similar to NetHack brass.

SlashTHEM

SlashTHEM adds the greater water elemental, though water elementals cannot grow up into them. Water elementals leave behind shallow water upon death, and are generated in the same levels as in SLASH'EM.

The Firefighter quest artifact, the Fire Chief Helmet, can be invoked to summon tame water elementals, with a 3⁄4 chance of generating a standard water elemental and a 1⁄4 chance of generating a greater one. The Storm Whistle is changed to instead summon tame ice elementals and ice vortices.

References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 45: elementals and home planes
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1012: max HP for elementals on home planes
  3. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1825: max HP gain for elementals on home planes
  4. ↑ dat/endgame.des in NetHack 3.6.7, line 457

A '''water elemental''', {{monsym|water elemental}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is an [[amphibious]], [[unsolid]] [[elemental]] that is [[strong]] and capable of [[swimming]].

A water elemental has a single strong claw attack, and possesses [[poison resistance]] and [[stoning resistance]].

==Generation==
Randomly generated water elementals may be [[peaceful]] towards [[neutral]] characters. Water elementals generated on the [[Plane of Water]] will have three times as many hit points.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|45|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=elementals and home planes}}{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1012|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=max HP for elementals on home planes}}{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1825|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=max HP gain for elementals on home planes}}

In addition to random generation, a water elemental may be generated as a [[minion]] of a neutral [[god]]. [[Quaff]]ing from a [[sink]] has a {{frac|20}} chance of generating a water elemental if they are not [[extinct]].

Water elementals appear among the random {{white|E}} that are part of the first [[quest]] [[monster class]] for [[Monk]]s, and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Monk quest]]. They also appear among the the random {{white|E}} that are part of the second quest class for [[Samurai]], and make up {{frac|6|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Samurai quest]].

Nineteen hostile water elementals are generated across the Plane of Water at level creation.{{refsrc|dat/endgame.des|457|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Water elementals are not a valid target for [[genocide]]. A water elemental [[Corpseless|does not leave a corpse]] upon death.

==Strategy==
Water elementals have the strongest single attack among elementals, but are incredibly slow at 6 base [[speed]] and lack any of the abilities that some other elementals possess, meaning they can easily be outrun and kited.

On the Plane of Water, the water elementals are usually the least threatening monsters present: most of the level is populated with [[sea monster]]s that can instantly kill a character via [[drowning]], making it common to read a blessed [[scroll of genocide]] immediately after entering the Plane. Once the Plane's drowning threats are dealt with, water elementals are considered an annoyance at worst, as most characters will be more than able to handle their melee attacks.

==History==
The water elemental first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], at least one water elemental is generated within the Cloud Bank of the [[Lawful Quest]] at level creation, with a {{frac|3|5}} chance of a second one being placed nearby.

Water elementals feature prominently in the [[Flame Mage quest]]: They are the first quest monster class for [[Flame Mage]]s, and make up {{frac|96|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on their quest. Several water elementals are also generated on each floor of the quest branch at level creation: six are generated on the home level, seven are generated on the filler levels, nine are generated on the locate level, and twelve are generated on the goal level.

The Ice Mage [[quest artifact]], [[The Storm Whistle]], can be [[invoked]] to summon tame water elementals.

===NetHack brass===
In [[NetHack brass]], water elementals are given an additional engulfing attack that can cause a [[delayed instadeath]] by [[strangulation]] (which is flavored as "drowning" while being distinct from [[drowning attack]]s) and a rust-inducing passive. This makes them among the more dangerous elementals to encounter, as their engulfing can suffocate you if you do not break out in time, and will often cause significant water damage to your even if you survive.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], {{frac|10}} of the monsters randomly generated on the Water Temple level of the [[Chaos Temple Quest]] will be water elementals.

Water elementals take double damage from the Horrid Wilting active power of [[Spirits (dNetHack)#Iris, Friend from Afar|Iris, Friend from Afar]].

===SpliceHack===
In [[SpliceHack]], a hostile water elemental is generated on the [[Plane of Ice]] at level creation.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], water elementals are given a rust-inducing passive and an additional engulfing attack that causes delayed instadeath by suffocation, similar to NetHack brass.

===SlashTHEM===
[[SlashTHEM]] adds the [[greater water elemental]], though water elementals cannot grow up into them. Water elementals leave behind [[shallow water]] upon death, and are generated in the same levels as in SLASH'EM.

The [[Firefighter]] quest artifact, the [[Fire Chief Helmet]], can be invoked to summon tame water elementals, with a {{frac|3|4}} chance of generating a standard water elemental and a {{frac|4}} chance of generating a greater one. The Storm Whistle is changed to instead summon tame [[ice elemental]]s and [[ice vortices]].
